_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1. Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies
The Rexnord Corporation, Link-Belt Bearing Division (Rexnord) facility is located at 7601 Rockville Road, Indianapolis, Indiana. Rexnord maintains on site one (1) propane tank, with a maximum capacity of 30,000 gallons (127,500 pounds). Propane is a listed flammable substance under the Risk Management Plan regulations found at 40 CFR 68 and is subject to those regulations since it is stored in quantities in excess of 10,000 pounds. It is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling propane to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to the personal health of employees as well as to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community. It is the policy of Rexnord to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations. Safety depends upon the manner in which Rexnord handles propane combined with the safety devices inherent in the design of the facility, the safe handling procedures that are used, and the training of Rexnord personnel.

The emergency response program at this facility is based upon the NPGA's LP-Gas Safety Handbook, "Guidelines for Developing Plant Emergency Procedures" and "How to Control LP-Gas Leaks and Fires".  The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority and notification of any potentially affected neighbors.

2. Description of the stationary source and regulated substances handled

Rexnord utilizes propane as a constituent for various furnace atmospheres and to supply the cracking gas to produce endothermic gas in endothermic gas generators. Propane is received by truck (transports) and stored in four storage tanks. This facility has equipment for unloading propane from railcar.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.  

The only regulated substance under section 112(r) handled at this fa

cility is propane.

The maximum amount of propane that can be stored at this plant is 127,500 pounds (30,000 gallons).

3. Worst-case release scenario and alternative release scenarios

Worst-Case Scenario. - Failure of one of our storage tanks when filled to the maximum amount would affect the other three tanks and would release 127,500 pounds of propane. Company policy limits the maximum filling capacity of each tank to 88% at 60 oF. It is assumed that the entire contents are released as vapor, which would find an ignition source, 10% of the released quantity is assumed to participate in the resulting explosion.  

The distance to the endpoint of 1-psi for the worst-case scenario is 0.5 miles.

Alternative Scenario. - A pull-away causing failure of a 25-foot length of 4-inch hose. The excess flow valves function to stop the flow. The content of the hose, which is 69 pounds, is released. The resulting unconfined vapor travels to the lower flammability limit. The release leads to a vapor cloud explosion (endpoint 1-psi). The distance to the endpoint for the lower flammability limit for the alternative scenario is 106 feet or 0.02 miles (report as less than 0.1 mile).

4. General accidental release prevention program and the specific prevention steps.

This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations. This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with NFPA-58. All of the employees handling propane have been thoroughly trained.

5. Five-year accident history.

In the process of handling propane at this facility, there have not been any accidental releases of propane that led to deaths or injuries of people on- or off-site or response or restoration activities at environmental receptors in the last five years. None of the employees or contractors has been involved in any accidents related to the hazardous substances defined in section 112(r) that is stored or handled at this facility.

6

. Emergency response program.

RexnordA?s personnel are not trained to respond to accidental releases of regulated substances. In the event of a release at the facility, the Wayne Township Fire Department would be notified immediately.
